article-meta.issue-title: Special Topical Issue on Nonlinear Energy Harvesting

abstract.p: The effect of large deflection on the mechanical and electrical behaviors of flexible piezoelectric energy harvesters has not been well studied. A generalized nonlinear coupled finite element circuit simulation approach is presented in this article to study the performance of energy harvesters subjected to large deflections. The method presented is validated experimentally using three test examples consisting of (a) a static case, (b) a free vibration case, and (c) a forced vibration case. Under static conditions (when the transverse tip deflection exceeds a quarter of the cantilever length), large deflections cause geometric stiffening of the structure that reduces the tip deflection of the generator when compared to linear (i.e. small-deflection) behavior. For a cantilever generator under dynamic conditions, geometric stiffening, inertial softening, and nonlinear damping effects become significant. Large deflections both shift the resonant frequency and increase damping and can thus cause a significant reduction in output voltage when compared with small-deflection linear theory. In the finite element generator model studied in this article, these nonlinear dynamic effects become significant when the transverse tip deflection exceeds 35% of the beam length.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Piezoelectric energy harvesting is being actively researched for continuous powering of small electronic devices, such as wireless sensors. Coupled with low power electronic circuits, energy harvesters electronic circuits, energy harvesters have a significant potential to reduce the reliance on, or even eliminate the necessity of batteries to power these devices. This would save on the lifetime cost of the sensors and decrease or eliminate the periodic need to recharge the batteries. Most piezoelectric energy harvesters studied to date consist of a bending member, or beam, made from stiff ceramic layers (such as lead zirconate titanate (PZT)) that act as mechanical resonators tuned to the dominant frequency of the ambient vibration source. Even though the generator is designed to be in resonance, the deformations of the beam are typically small. The small displacement ensures that the beam does not fail in fatigue. Recently, flexible piezoelectric resonators (either made from plastic polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) or ceramic-fiber composites) have been proposed for a number of applications, such as extraction of energy from fluid flows and powering of wearable electronic devices. For example, Akaydin et al. (2010) have demonstrated a flexible PVDF-based cantilever energy generator subjected to periodic vortices shed from a bluff body. In the Akaydin et al. (2009) experiments, the cantilever beam’s tip deflections are relatively large (greater than 30% of the beam length). Although the mechanical behavior of the generator was modeled using small-deflection Euler–Bernoulli beam theory, the effect of ignoring large displacement is unknown. Flexible piezoelectric generators undergoing small and large deformations are also of interest in low-frequency structural vibration harvesting, commonly found in large-scale structures such as bridges and buildings (Elvin et al., 2006) and for human powered harvesting, for example, from walking (von Büren et al., 2006) and from shaking by hand (Paradiso and Starner, 2005).

Previously, the static behavior of flexible piezoelectric, cantilever beams under large displacements has been studied by Mukherjee and Chaudhuri (2002) using the finite element (FE) method. Kulkarni and Bajoria (2007) formulated a large-deflection theory for piezoelectric shells, including shear deformation. Most of the work in large-displacement piezoelectric behavior has been focused either on the theoretical formulation of the governing differential equations or on control theory (Pai et al., 1993; Yi et al., 2000; Zhou and Tzou, 2000). Furthermore, only open-circuit voltage and actuation responses have been investigated under large structural displacements. Recently, the effect of nonlinear piezoelectric behavior (including both stress stiffening and nonlinear electromechanical coupling) on piezoelectric energy harvesting has been studied theoretically by Triplett and Quinn (2009). In attempting to increase the operating bandwidth of the energy harvesters, a significant amount of work has been done on modeling generalized nonlinear stiffening behavior, by adding a nonlinear stiffness term (so called Duffing-type stiffening) to the mechanical oscillator equation (see, for example, Daqaq, 2010). To the knowledge of the authors, the experimental validation of these large-displacement models has not been published.

Previously Elvin and Elvin (2009) have presented a coupled, time-marching, FE, and circuit simulation method for analyzing piezoelectric generators. In this general method, since the FE procedure is used at each time step, the structural generator can undergo large displacements and even large deformations. The mechanical response of the generator is electromechanically coupled to a standard circuit simulation program to obtain the response of any (linear or nonlinear) electronic components attached to the generator. The electrical response of the circuit is then electromechanically coupled back to the FE model. The advantage of the Elvin and Elvin (2009) method is that arbitrary structural geometries and nonlinear behavior can be calculated using a standard FE approach, while circuits of any complexity can be solved using standard electrical simulators.

The aim of this article is to present a framework to account for large deformations in energy harvesting and then to investigate theoretically and experimentally the large displacements of cantilever piezoelectric generators under both static and dynamic loading. Some practical guidelines for the applicability of small-deflection theory are also presented.

sec.title: Coupled FE circuit analysis
sec.p: Following the coupled FE analysis (FEA) circuit forward marching scheme of Elvin and Elvin (2009), the structural part of the problem is solved using a standard FE program (ABAQUS® by Simulia in this case) and the electrical part of the problem is solved using a circuit simulator such as SPICE. The two analyses are coupled using equivalent loads in the structural simulation and equivalent voltages in the circuit simulation (Figure 2).

caption.p: Schematic depiction of the coupled finite element–circuit simulation method.

sec.p: In summary, at each time step, the structural equations are solved using a standard FE analysis. These equations are of the form (Elvin and Elvin, 2009)

where u are the nodal displacements; M is the mass matrix; D is the damping matrix; K is the stiffness matrix, which can be nonlinear; F is the applied load vector; and Fp is the electromechanical (coupling) equivalent force vector. The over-dots indicate differentiation with respect to time.

The force vector Fp is calculated from the piezoelectric axial force (Np) and moment (Mp) given in equation (12). It should be emphasized that in the case of large deformation, the axial force (Np) is the so called follower force as shown in Figure 2, that is, the axial force direction changes in time but always remains tangential to the neutral axis of the beam.
The electrical equations, which are solved at each time step using a circuit simulator, are of the form
where i is the electrical current in the piezoelectric circuit and C is the piezoelectric capacitance. The electromechanical coupling voltage, νo, is calculated using equation (6).

For many flexible piezoelectric generators, the electromechanical coupling coefficient (i.e. e31) is relatively small and the structural and electrical domains can then be decoupled, that is, the piezoelectric coupling forces are much smaller than the applied forces (Fp

The structural model is first solved, and the displacements from the model are then used to solve the circuit equation (i.e. equation (14)). Since a typical nonlinear analysis might require very small time stepping, the decoupling of the electrical and structural domains can greatly reduce the required computational effort.

sec.title: Example 1: piezoelectric cantilever under static loading
sec.p: In order to validate experimentally the large-deflection structural FE model, two-node large-displacement Euler–Bernoulli beam elements with three degrees of freedom per node (implemented in ABAQUS) were used to model the quasi-static behavior of a PVDF unimorph (i.e. a structure made of only one piezoelectric layer attached to an electromechanically passive structural layer). The cantilever beam was subjected to open-circuit conditions. Figure 3 shows the experimental setup. The tip vertical deflections (δv), horizontal (δh) deflections, and rotation (α) of a cantilever unimorph PVDF generator (MSIUSA Inc. with properties given in Table 1) under incremental quasi-static loading were obtained from digitized photographs (taken with a Casio EX-F1 with 2 MP resolution).

sec.p: This example problem is solved dynamically using the open-circuit FE model at a force rate of F = 0.05 N/s. This loading rate can be considered to be quasi-static because the natural frequency of the investigated cantilever beam is approximately 50 Hz. Since in the static case, an infinite resistance oscilloscope is needed to measure the open-circuit voltage across the piezoelectric, this case is used only to verify the large-deflection structural predictions made by the FE model. Figure 4 compares the theoretical FE large-displacement simulations with experimental results. In this figure, the vertical and horizontal tip displacements are normalized by the beam length. The rotation is normalized by π/2 and the load is normalized by L2/(YpIp) (Gere and Timoshenko, 1987). Furthermore, there is a near perfect match between the FE model and the analytical nonlinear cantilever solution (Gere and Timoshenko, 1987). Both the linear and Duffing-type stiffening solutions are included to show that the linear model starts to break down for tip deflections of δv/L > 0.25, and the Duffing model begins to break down for δv/L > 0.5. By definition, the small-deformation theory is unable to capture the horizontal deflections, δh.

caption.p: Comparison of the normalized nonlinear finite element model for (a) vertical tip deflection δv, (b) horizontal tip deflection δh, and (c) tip rotation α of the cantilever unimorph with experimental measurements. Ip refers to the equivalent piezoelectric second moment of area. The Gere and Timoshenko (1987) results coincide with the finite element model results.

In the static case, k = 3YI/L3 is the linear term and b is the Duffing stiffening term. The Duffing term (b) used in Figure 4 was calculated by using a least squares fit to the FE results up to δv/L < 0.5. The Duffing equation is unable to capture accurately deflections larger than δv/L > 0.5 since higher order polynomial terms are needed in equation (15). It should be noted that if the entire force–displacement curve in Figure 4(a) is fitted, the mean absolute error in the vertical tip displacement for δv/L > 0.25 is approximately 10%.

The maximum stress at the base of the cantilever generator is calculated to be 32 MPa under the normalized load FL2/(YpIp) = 6, which is well within the linear d31 and elastic region for PVDF (as specified by MSIUSA Inc.)

For the open-circuit case, the output voltage is directly related to the rotation at the end of the piezoelectric layer (i.e. at Lp) as given by equation (8). In the present case, since Lp = L, the open-circuit voltage would be directly proportional to the tip rotation. Figure 4(c) shows that using small-deflection (i.e. linear) theory could significantly overpredict the open-circuit voltage. From a practical standpoint, large-deformation theory should thus be used when the tip deflection of a cantilever generator is expected to be greater than a quarter of the beam length (or when the tip rotation is greater than approximately 0.4 rad).

Under the maximum static loading (FL2/(YpIp) = 6), the theoretical open-circuit voltage is calculated to be vo = 63.3 V. This corresponds to an applied piezoelectric tip moment of Mp = 4.7 × 10−6 Nm (from equation (12)), which is much smaller than the applied moment M = 7.1 × 10−3 Nm in this case. Thus, if small-deflection linear theory is used, the tip deflection would be overpredicted by approximately 0.2% compared to the case when coupling is included. Hence, the decoupled FE circuit method was used for all subsequent simulations.

sec.title: Example 2: large-deformation ring-down of a piezoelectric cantilever
sec.p: In order to test the validity of the strain–voltage relationship in equations (6) to (8), the voltage generated by the PVDF unimorph cantilever in Example 1 was measured after the tip of the generator was subjected to a large initial deflection and then released to allow free vibration. Figure 5 shows an instantaneous view of the generator under large deformation during the ring-down test. The deformation history of the generator was captured at 300 frames per second using a Casio EX-F1 digital camera with a resolution of 0.2 MP. Two color LEGO® blocks were used as the tip mass (measured Mt = 3.15 g and calculated mass moment of inertia about the rotation axis of It = 150 g mm2). The centroids of the two blocks, identified as open circles in Figure 5, were first located using digital color-filtering and image-processing techniques (MATLAB® (MathWorks Inc.)). The slope of the straight line joining the two centroids was then used to calculate the tip rotation α[L]. The piezoelectric voltage during the test was measured using an oscilloscope with 10 MΩ impedance.

caption.p: Video image snap shot during the large-deformation ring-down test. The circles represent the centroids of the LEGO blocks. The line joining the centroids represents the tip rotation.

sec.p: The tip rotation was used to calculate the voltage across a 10 MΩ resistor using the electromechanical coupling voltage (vo from equations (6) to (8)) and subsequently to calculate the voltage across the resistor of the equivalent circuit model in Figure 2. The calculated equivalent circuit voltage and the measured voltage show good agreement (Figure 6). The calculated and the measured results were synchronized by matching the time to reach the first peak. The close agreement between the voltage calculated due to the tip rotation and the experimentally measured voltage confirms the large-deflection strain-voltage relationships in equations (6) to (8).

caption.p: The equivalent circuit calculated (solid) and the measured (dots) voltages across a 10 MΩ resistor. For clarity, only every second measured point is shown.

sec.p: The ring-down test was simulated using the coupled FE equivalent circuit model with parameters in Table 1, a tip mass of Mt = 3.15 g, moment of inertia of It = 150 g mm2, and a resistance of R = 10 MΩ. The FE software ABAQUS with explicit time integration was used to model the nonlinear structural response of the generator. A custom written MATLAB program was used to calculate the equivalent circuit response. It should be noted that only mass proportional damping can be used in explicit ABAQUS analysis and damping is not included with point masses and mass inertia elements. In order to overcome the later restriction, a beam element with the same equivalent mass and mass moment of inertia was added to the tip of the beam. Since the first half cycle response is strongly influenced by the release time from the initial displacement, the first half cycle was ignored and the simulation was started at the measured displacement after the first half cycle. The initial displacement was applied in the FE model by a quasi-static vertical tip force until the tip displacement matched the deflection measured from the still video image (i.e. the same method as in Example 1 was used). In the model, the force was released in 0.01 s, which is much faster than the period of the first resonance (i.e. 0.22 s) of the piezoelectric generator. The initial displacement after the first half cycle is approximately δv/L = 0.5, and therefore, large-deflection theory applies (see Figure 4). The comparison of the model and experimental results are shown in Figure 7 for a damping coefficient of ζ = 4.3% as measured from a standard ring-down test with small initial tip displacement (δv/L < 0.1).

caption.p: Comparison of the experimentally measured voltage across the resistor and the model predictions with a damping ratio of ζ = 4.3%. The first half cycle of the experimental results is ignored.

sec.p: The model and experimentally measured piezoelectric voltages show good agreement. It should be noted that there are no fitting parameters used in the model in Figure 7. The fundamental resonant mode of the model (4.48 Hz) seems to be slightly lower than the resonant frequency of the actual experiment (4.52 Hz), as can be seen by the small shift in phase between the two plots that increases with time. Since electrical energy is dissipated through the load resistor, in reality, a small amount of electromechanical damping is present in the generator. This damping is ignored in the decoupled FE circuit analysis model. For the small-deflection case, the decoupled dynamic solution thus slightly overpredicts the maximum output voltage, which would be the equivalent of approximately ζ = 4.33% damping for the coupled case when compared to ζ = 4.3% for the decoupled case. For the weakly coupled case considered, this difference is negligible and can be ignored since it is well within the experimental measurement error of the damping coefficient.

sec.title: Example 3: large-deformation behavior of a piezoelectric cantilever under base excitation
sec.p: In order to validate experimentally the large-deflection model under realistic energy harvesting conditions (e.g. an energy harvester shaken by hand), the support of the PVDF unimorph generator in Example 2 was moved horizontally by hand at approximately the resonant frequency of the generator in order to achieve large deflections in the beam. The displacement of the base was captured using digital processing techniques from images captured with a high-speed video camera as explained in Example 2 and shown in Figure 8(a). Since the base of the generator was not moved back to the starting position, Figure 8(a) shows a residual displacement of approximately 4 mm. This residual displacement is also incorporated into the model. Using the same model parameters, as in Example 2, the base excitation was used as an input into the FE model to predict the generated voltage through a R = 10 MΩ resistor; the computed voltage compared well with the experimentally measured piezoelectric voltage as shown Figure 8(b).

caption.p: (a) Base displacement time history applied to the piezoelectric generator and (b) measured and calculated piezoelectric generator voltage output.

sec.p: As in Example 2, the model slightly underpredicts the experimental resonant frequency, which causes a small phase shift between the computed and measured results. The maximum vertical displacement of the tip mass during the base excitation test was δv/L 0.7. For this example, the response of the generator calculation assuming small-deflection theory would overpredict the maximum generated voltage by 40% and the maximum power (i.e. v2max/R) by nearly 100%.

The response as calculated by the FE-electric circuit model for the PVDF generator of Examples 2 and 3 under increasing harmonic base excitation is shown in Figure 9. A load resistance of R = 1/(ωC) = 25 MΩ, where ω is the resonant frequency of the generator, was used in these simulations; this corresponds to the maximum power output for a weakly electromechanically coupled generator (Liao and Sodano, 2009).

caption.p: Comparison of normalized transfer functions for (a) maximum voltage and (b) maximum tip displacement for various base acceleration amplitudes ranging from 0.5 m/s2 to 4 m/s2.

sec.p: As the generator undergoes increasing tip displacement, there is an associated increase in the apparent resonant frequency due to nonlinear geometric stiffening (as indicated by the shift of the resonant frequency with base-amplitude excitation in Figure 9). For plotting clarity, the generated voltage (|Voltage|) and average tip deflection (|δv|) are normalized by the magnitude of the base acceleration. The resonant frequency of the generator changes from 4.48 Hz in the small-deformation case (base excitation of 0.5 m/s2 or less) to 4.64 Hz in the very large-deformation case (base excitation of 4 m/s2). Using small-deflection theory would also overpredict the average generated power at resonance in the largest deflection case (base excitation of 4 m/s2) by approximately 90%. In the case when the largest deflection resonator was designed to operate at the small-deflection resonance (i.e. 4.48 Hz), the maximal voltage output from the generator would be 36% smaller than predicted by small-deflection theory. For intermediate large deflections (i.e. a base excitation of around 2 m/s2 in Figure 9), the resonant tip deflection is approximately δv/L 0.6 and corresponds to a 20% underprediction of tip displacement and 10% underprediction in output voltage when compared to small-deflection theory. There is a small deviation from linear behavior at 1 m/s2 when the tip deflection is approximately δv/L 0.35.

The equivalent to the Duffing equation for dynamic loading has been previously analyzed extensively, and a simplified single mode model undergoing relatively large deflections and ignoring rotary inertia is given by (Oueini and Nayfeh, 1999)

where the first three terms are the linear dynamic terms as in equation (13), α1 is the nonlinear stiffening (Duffing) term, α2 and α3 are the nonlinear inertia terms, and F(t) is the dynamic force term, which could be due to base excitation. Nonlinear damping terms (as could be introduced by air drag) have been omitted. The results of the FE model (Figure 9) show the effect of three nonlinearities. First, there is an increase in frequency of the peak response with increasing base excitation. Second, there is a decrease in peak magnitude with increasing base excitation, and third, at the highest base excitation, the response of the generator approaches the jump-instability condition.

The large-displacement behavior of a cantilever beam can show both geometric stiffening (i.e. hardening), which tends to shift the peak frequency response at large displacements to the right, and inertial softening, which tends to shift the peak frequency response to the left. The actual magnitude of the shift in frequency is dependent on a linear combination of the hardening and softening terms in equation (1) known as |α| (Malatkar, 2003). The decrease of peak amplitude response with base excitation amplitude is due to nonlinear damping effects. It should be noted that for large displacements, the cantilever beam model in equation (13) is typically modified with nonlinear terms that are fitted to experimental data (Malatkar, 2003). The critical base acceleration amplitude (acr) required for the nonlinear amplitude jump response, seen at a base excitation of approximately 4 m/s2, is a function of the total nonlinear stiffness |α| and damping (Malatkar, 2003)
In the FE model, the damping ratio increases with excitation amplitude, which tends to further increase the critical base acceleration.

sec.title: Discussion of the effect of electromechanical coupling
sec.p: All experimental cases studied in this article focused on PVDF generators, which are flexible and have low electromechanical coupling. At present, there is a significant research effort to develop flexible piezoelectric materials with high coupling coefficients (Chen et al., 2010; Qi et al., 2010; Swallow et al., 2008). Although a complete set of structural and electrical properties are not yet available for these materials, it is interesting to compare the effect of electromechanical coupling of these devices with the PVDF generator analyzed here. Consider a hypothetical piezoelectric material with all properties similar to PVDF (i.e. given in Table 1) except for a fivefold increase in the e31 electromechanical coefficient. This coupling is comparable to the best reported flexible piezoelectric material (Qi et al., 2010). Figure 10 shows the comparison of the generated voltage assuming full electromechanical coupling and no electromechanical coupling. Two cases are considered, the first (Figure 10a) for weak electromechanical coupling as used throughout this article and the second (Figure 10b), for the case where the electromechanical coupling coefficient has been increased fivefold. The analysis is based on a linear, single degree-of-freedom model with no rotary inertia and is similar to the previous work of Elvin et al. (2006). The difference between a fully coupled electromechanical analysis and an uncoupled analysis for low electromechanical coupling shows a difference of less than 2% in generated voltage, and this justifies the uncoupled analysis assumption used in this article. For the case of strong electromechanical coupling, the uncoupled analysis significantly overpredicts the peak-generated voltage by 38%. Furthermore, in the strong electromechanical coupling case, the peak frequency for the uncoupled case underpredicts the peak frequency in the coupled case by approximately 2%. Neglecting electromechanical coupling can also become significant at lower damping ratios. For example, if the linear analysis was performed on the beam with parameters given in Table 1 (again ignoring rotary inertia and assuming R = 25 MΩ), but with a 1% damping ratio, the difference in peak resonant voltage between the uncoupled and coupled electromechanical analysis would be approximately 5%. Thus, although the uncoupled piezoelectric analysis presented in this article is justified due to the weak electromechanical coupling and relatively high damping ratio, as flexible piezoelectric materials with higher electromechanical coupling coefficients are developed, the effect of this coupling on nonlinear geometric stiffening would have to be examined more closely.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The generalized method of analyzing a piezoelectric generator under large deformation has been presented in this article. The method relies on a coupled, time-stepping algorithm that independently analyzes (a) the large-deformation response of the generator using a nonlinear FE code and (b) the electric response of the circuit. Equivalent forces in the FE model and piezoelectric voltages in the circuits are used at each time step to obtain the electromechanical response of the generator. In the case of weak electromechanical coupling, the structural and electrical physical domains can be decoupled, which greatly increases the computational speed.

Neglecting the structural nonlinearity caused by large deflection can severely overpredict the available output power of a piezoelectric energy harvester. This effect becomes significant when the vertical tip deflection is greater than a portion the generator length. It was shown that for tip deflections greater than a quarter the length of the beam (δv > 0.25L), the structural response under a static point load applied at the tip of a cantilever beam begins to deviate significantly from linear behavior. The model results for dynamic excitations at resonance are similar. Adding Duffing-type, nonlinear stiffening terms for the static cases can improve the accuracy of the structural model for tip deflections up to half the beam length (δv < 0.5L). Since converted power (P) is related to the square of the voltage generated over the electrical load resistance, the effect on output power is even more pronounced for large deflections. In the dynamic large-deflection case, the effects of stress stiffening, inertial softening, and nonlinear damping can significantly change the response of the generator when compared with a linear model. For example, a generator designed to match the dominant ambient vibration frequency under small deflections can be significantly detuned under large deflections, which would lead to a further loss in output power. Since linear models are significantly less computationally intensive than nonlinear models, from a practical standpoint, it is advisable to first use a linear model to predict deflections. If these deflections exceed a certain percentage of the overall structure’s length, a nonlinear model should be used. For example, for cantilever generators, if the tip deflection exceeds one quarter of the length, nonlinear effects have to be taken into account.

Further work is required to characterize the point where the linear model breaks down for harvester geometries other than the cantilever. Future research should also be directed at analyzing and performing experiments to validate the effect of high-electromechanical coupling when the generators are subject to large deflections.
